MAIN ESTIMATES, 1961 (Cont.)


    Head 19 -

    Question again proposed.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, over and above the questions raised by the Member for the Southern Islands, I wish to raise this particular question. Mr Speaker, Sir, you will notice, under sub-head 18, the words "Temporary Staff" appear. As far as this House has been able to understand, it would appear that the parking meter scheme has come to be regarded as something which will be permanent in Singapore. If that is so, is there any point in keeping the staff temporary? In those circumstances, should not the staff be made permanent?

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, I will take this opportunity, first of all, to review the position of the car parks. Since we started opening the pay-as-you-park scheme on the 21st of December last year, up to the 30th of last month we have collected altogether a revenue of

Column: 308

$351,337. The total charges amounted to $168,260. That brings into the Consolidated Fund a profit of $183,077. Apart from the dollars and cents of the business, it is more gratifying to note that the scheme has given employment to 77 parking attendants and six other staff. The reason why the staff engaged on this scheme has been labelled temporary is that when the scheme was initiated, it came under the supervision of the Registrar of Vehicles, which was then a department of the City Council. As Members in the House know, we are now in the process of integrating City Council services with the Central Government. The staff engaged on this scheme must, therefore, come under the temporary category, as distinct from those on the establishment. In other words, they are paid a provident fund, but they do not receive a pension. Moreover, such staff are not transferable to any other department of the Government. In this connection, I may draw as a basis for comparison other staff who are employed on schemes like the Work Brigade. Members of the Work Brigade are also on the temporary establishment, as distinct from those on the civil list. That, I hope, will answer the question raised by the Member for Farrer Park.

    Yesterday, the Member for the Southern Islands mentioned that some motorists were dissatisfied with the service provided in the car parks. I would like it very much if the Member for the Southern Islands could give me specific instances where my car park attendants have been discourteous, and I will promise him that investigations will be made.

    Ever since the car park scheme was started, I have received only two letters of complaint addressed personally to me. Both of them have been investigated. One of them was found to be the fault of the motorist himself; and in the case of the other one, we found that the car park attendant was not in any way responsible for scratches being made on his car.

    The car park attendants are provided with uniforms after their probationary period of three months. Those who are newly engaged are in mufti, but after

Column: 309

they have been tried and they satisfy the senior parking attendant of their capabilities, they are confirmed and are issued with uniforms. However, they are not given a number, and the idea put forward by the Member for the Southern Islands that car park attendants should be so distinguished will be looked into. Nonetheless, I would like to inform the Member for the Southern Islands that in every car park there is always a senior parking attendant who is located in a kiosk, and if any motorist has any complaints to make against a car park attendant, he is at complete liberty to go straight to the senior parking attendant and lodge his complaint, or, alternatively, write a letter to the Registrar of Vehicles and his complaint will be attended to. But in justice to the car park attendants, I would say that not all the blame falls upon them. It has been brought to my attention by the car park attendants themselves that many motorists are selfish. They park overtime; they then quietly steal into the car park and drive off without paying any surcharge. Naturally, when they are stopped by the car park attendant, some of these motorists begin to protest quite violently. I would say that my sympathy is more with the car park attendants than with the motorists, because the job of a car park attendant is not an easy one. He has to stay out in the sun or in the rain to look after the car park lots, and he has to be patient with motorists who can be adamant, stubborn and may even be non-co-operative.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, in his speech just now, the Deputy Prime Minister described the car park attendants as his car park attendants. If they are his car park attendants, it would seem to appear, Sir, that the allegation outside that these car park attendants are P.A.P. members has a foundation. As Dr Toh himself, he has no car park attendants, but as a member of the Government, yes.

    The car park attendants are the servants of the Government and therefore the servants of the public.

Column: 310



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: You see, Mr Speaker, I am quite different from the Member for Cairnhill -

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Ex-Member for Havelock.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I expect loyalty from those who serve under me, as the head of my Ministry; so it is natural that those who are working in my departments should expect a degree of loyalty from their Minister. When I refer to the car park attendants as my car park attendants, I refer to the civil servants equally as our civil servants, or the civil servants in my department as my civil servants. But I presume the Member for Cairnhill, when he was once upon a time Chief Minister, never had that sense of bringing the civil servants in sympathy with the policies he was carrying out at that time, and so he could never at any time refer to his civil servants as his civil servants. However, I would like to kill the charge made by the Member for Cairnhill that the car park attendants are all P.A.P. members. Car park attendants are appointed not because of their party affiliations; and if the Member for Cairnhill wishes to know, I can inform him that these attendants were recruited from the Labour Exchange. They were selected by a committee set up under the City Council's Welfare and Labour Section. Most of the candidates have come from the Work Brigade. That is in keeping with the declaration made by the Government some months back that in future most of the Division IV posts will be filled by members of the Work Brigade, and we see no reason why car park attendants should not also be recruited from this Work Brigade. However, to lay the charge that they are P.A.P. members and are therefore appointed as car park attendants is quite unfair.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have never laid any charge at all. I said there is an allegation outside that car park attendants are P.A.P. members, and that is why the Minister has described them as his car park attendants. His reply now shows that although he cannot say that all car park attendants

Column: 311

are P.A.P. members, he does admit that there are quite a good number of P.A.P. members who are car park attendants.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, what particular party the car park attendants belong to is none of my business. They are chosen because of their (1) honesty, (2) ability to deal with the public. This is a Division IV post really where members of the public service have important relationships with the public at large. No one is taken on because he is a P.A.P. member, but he is taken on if he can show that, first of all, he is honest, that he will not pinch money, or that he will defraud the motorists. That is the simple criterion for the selection. The Member for Cairnhill has said that he has not made the allegation but by repeating it here, he has made an imputation and, therefore, it is up to me to clear the point.

2.45 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, English is indeed a difficult language. If I were to keep on saying what I have said, it will not get through to the Deputy Prime Minister.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, may I come back to the point of my question, leaving aside the constitutional issues involved in the Minister calling his staff "my staff"? On "Temporary Staff", the Deputy Prime Minister gave the House the impression that these people will continue to be designated temporary, even though the parking meter scheme has come to be a permanent feature of the Budget, and he sought an analogy with members of the Work Brigade. The point there is quite different. The members of the Work Brigade are only there in order to carry out certain schemes of the Government, and if those schemes are not voted for from year to year, then the need for the Work Brigade goes. But here where the parking meter scheme has become a feature of our national life - and I expect it to be a permanent feature - should employees working on that scheme continue to be labelled "temporary"? I do not think it is fair to them.

Column: 312



    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, it seems to me that the Minister concerned has given clarification at length, but he has not clarified my point. Possibly he thought that the reason why I brought up this amendment was that the workers are P.A.P. members.

    My point is that the service given by the parking attendants is not satisfactory. Their uniform cannot be distinguished from that of drivers. When we wish to park our cars, we have to look around for the parking attendants, and sometimes it takes about ten minutes for one to come along. A person who uses these parking places is usually one who has important business to attend to, and he cannot afford to waste time. Therefore, if he has to look around for an attendant, I feel that the service is not satisfactory. It is only right that the Government should look into this matter. The attendants could be given a distinctive uniform so that they could be easily distinguished from other people in the parking places. That is the reason why I brought up this amendment.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: In reply to the Member for the Southern Islands about motorists having to wait for some time before they can find a car park attendant, I would like to inform the House that each attendant has to look after 26 parking lots. If we give an allowance for absences due to sickness, leave, and so on, on the average it works out to each attendant having to look after 30 parking lots. One way of solving the problem, of course, would be to engage more car parking attendants so that one attendant can look after 15 parking lots. But that would not be economical for the simple reason that if one car parking lot is full, it remains so for hours, and then we will have idle attendants and under-worked staff. It has never been brought to my attention as a specific complaint that a motorist has got to wait as long as ten minutes for a car parking attendant to come to him. But if, as I have said previously, the Member for the Southern Islands could state in which particular car parking lot he experienced

Column: 313

such a difficulty, I will assure him that all these little problems could be ironed out.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, with due respect to the Deputy Prime Minister, he has not yet answered my question.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I have forgotten to answer the question raised by the Member for Farrer Park. I said just now that the staff are temporary because we are now in the process of integrating the City Council services with the central government, and until that is completed, they do not yet come under the control of the Establishment Office. But presumably, when integration is completed, they will come under the control of the Ministry of Finance. The Establishment Office will then be in a position to decide what services are temporary and what services are to be permanent.

    Mr Rajah: As the answer of the Deputy Prime Minister is that the staff will cease to be temporary when integration does take place, I am satisfied.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I have said it is up to the Ministry of Finance.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri(In Malay): As a result of the clarification given by the Deputy Prime Minister, I beg leave to withdraw.

Column: 314



    Item (1) of sub-head 16 reads "Co-operative Education...$1,500". I seek information as to whether the Government is going to encourage the expansion of co-operative societies in Singapore, or is this matter to be treated as "frozen"? If one looks at the expenditure for 1959, one will find that over $5,000 has been allocated for this purpose. I cannot find any portion of this expenditure being allocated elsewhere.

    Apart from that, I would like to bring to the notice of this House the sad state of affairs in some co-operative societies which have been established for quite some time. There is now a shortage of officers to run them successfully. Previously, there was an officer who received training abroad and, as far as I know, this officer has now been transferred to another department; and he has been replaced by his assistant who is short of staff to help him in his job. I would like to say that several long-established co-operative societies will be forced to close down for the reason that they cannot function successfully. This can be attributed to the fact that their members are not very active. In particular, I know of two co-operative societies in the Southern Islands which are run by officers who have a limited knowledge of how to run them. They need guidance and education from the proper co-operative department. As a result of the shortage of co-operative officers skilled in administrative work, there is no doubt that some of these co-operative societies do not receive the guidance that they should receive. The co-operative movement should be expanded and the societies should be guided to run on economic lines. It is appropriate therefore for the Government, if it is their intention to see the expansion of the co-operative movement, to engage more Co-operative Officers, keep an eye on the existing co-operative societies, and render all assistance to these Officers by disseminating the principles of co-operative societies, and so on.

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Tan Kia Gan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the provision of $1,500 for Co-operative Education is intended for the purpose of defraying expenses for persons attending talks and lectures on co-operative principles, organisation and methods, accounting systems, etc. during the time when they are free.

    Just now the Member for the Southern Islands mentioned an officer who was trained and later transferred to another Department. This is a matter which happened at the time when I was not in the Ministry of National Development. But as far as the Ministry under me is concerned, we know that the officer who is in charge of co-operatives will be retiring very soon, and we are looking forward to recruiting a young man who could be trained, so that he could help in giving lectures to officers of co-operative societies all over the Island to revive the activities of such societies.

    In the year 1960, due to a reorganisation of the Department and preparatory work in strengthening the co-operative movement, not much work was done to give such lectures to officers of co-operative societies. But I can assure the Member for the Southern Islands that when the training of a new officer has been finalised, measures will be taken to improve facilities to train officers of co-operative societies to revive the activities of such societies.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri(In Malay): Mr Speaker, in view of the assurance given by the Minister, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 20 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of sub-head 17.

    In this provision, the vote says, "Allowances to part-time inoculators, rural organisers and drivers". I wish to seek information from the Minister concerned whether the increase in the provision

Column: 316

is for additional strength of inoculators from Government service, or whether it is to provide inoculation courses for the rural people. As far as I know, there are no inoculation facilities in the Southern Islands, so that the islanders have to come to Singapore for the inoculation of their poultry.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Mr Speaker, Sir, part-time inoculators are persons employed from the rural areas to work in the same district where they come from. All of them have a rural background and are engaged in agriculture in one form or another. Their main functions are to carry out pig and poultry inoculation for farmers, under supervision.

    At present there are 33 part-time inoculators, and 14 other part-time inoculators are engaged. That accounts for the additional expenditure stated in the Estimates. The 14 part-time inoculators are specially recruited to carry out the inoculation of young chicks. It is intended to inoculate these young chicks at Telok Ayer Quarantine Station when they are a day old, so that protection will be given to them. When the chicks are six days old, another inoculation is done free of charge. The reason why I engage these 14 other part-time inoculators is that we want to provide better services throughout the island of Singapore, including the Southern Islands.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Mr Rajah: I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 21 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (2) of sub-head 5.

    Item (2) of sub-head 5 says, "Istana Negara Domain - Gardener, Grade II, and Other Temporary Staff". Mr Speaker, Sir, two points arise out of this. The first point is: why should the staff continue to remain temporary, although integration has taken place some considerable time ago, and therefore the

Column: 317

reasons which the Hon. the Deputy Prime Minister advanced for the temporary nature of this staff do not apply? The second point is: there is a vote "Yang di-Pertuan Negara" under Head 1, and I submit that this particular vote should appear under Head 1, so that the public would know exactly what it costs the State to maintain the Yang di-Pertuan Negara.

Here again, I take it that the maintenance of the Istana Negara Domain concerns all the grounds in the domain and that the necessary equipment and fertilisers and insecticides are required to maintain the domain. I would submit again that they should properly appear under Head 1.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Farrer Park, I think, wants to know why the temporary staff remain temporary. The provision for this temporary staff is also shown for 1960.     Mr Rajah: The other point, Mr Speaker, Sir, involved in the question raised by me is the question of the Istana Negara Domain, which has certain items of expenditure under it. This may appear to be a small matter, Mr Speaker, Sir, but I think the principle

If that is so, then I think it would not be correct, because other quarters occupied by Government servants are not maintained by the Government.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware of what the Member for Farrer Park has just said, that is, about Government servants staying in the Istana Negara Domain and whether the grounds are being kept by these employees. Is it then the intention of Government that these two posts should be abolished, or is it because of the question of integration that token votes have been put in order that, during the course of the ensuing year, some arrangement might be made as to what the salaries of these two posts should be.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Mr Speaker, Sir, under the City Council integration plan, the City Engineer's Department has been merged with the Public Works Department to form one organisation. Hence the emolument of the Director of Public Works is no longer necessary, and a token provision has been entered in the Estimates. Under the scheme, which is under consideration, for the reorganization of the P.W.D. and the City Engineer's Department as an integrated department, one of the two posts of City Engineer and the Director of Public Works will be abolished.
